newsitem.title: MOROCCO: Morocco's Eqdom raises capital to $19.1 mln.
newsitem.headline: Morocco's Eqdom raises capital to $19.1 mln.

text.p: Morocco's credit firm Eqdom, said on Monday it was to increase its capital to 166.6 million dirhams ($19.1 million) from 111.1 million dirhams ($12.7 million).
"Eqdom decided to increase its capital in two simultanous operations of stock split and rights issue to 166.5 million dirhams," the firm said.
The company said the stock will be increased to 1.6 million shares from 1.1 million shares. It gave no date.
Eqdom, Morocco's first consumer credit company, was set up in 1974 by two government owned organisations, the Societe Nationale d'Investissement and Caisse de Depot et de Gestion.
In 1995, as part of its privatisation programme, the government sold 18 percent of its share capital through a public offering on the stock market.

According to the Casablanca Finance Intermediation (CFI), Eqdom has extended its activity form providing civil servants with small credits for the purchase of household appliances to a larger scale of personal lending.

"Personal lending has been growing rapidly over the past few years and accounted for 48 percent of new loans granted in 1995 ... It accounts for an increasingly large proportion of the total loan book and is likely to push through the 50 percent barrier in 1996," CFI said in a recent report.
Eqdom, is among the 46-listed companies on the Casablanca stock market. Its shares were traded on the bourse on Monday at 1,009 dirhams, up 29 dirhams on the previous session.
The total dividend paid in 1996 will amount to 18.9 million dirhams, a pay-out of only 16.6 percent of 1995 profit or 21 percent of 1996 estimated net profit, CFI added.
